dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the most typical scenes of the day: a mass picket  line outside a textile or shoe factory. And the picketing anything but peaceful; the demonstrators are in direct  conflict with the police, who are trying to keep an entra open for strike-breakers. Whatever the general action, a  small segment of struggle breaks off from it, and it is t that our CAMERA picks up: some police chasing some picket or some pickets chasing some strike-breakers, the one fac pursuing the other up an alley with violent intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of the pursuers catch up to the pursued and assa them with clubs or other weapons. The fighting is bitter, dirty and noisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eight men gathered here in a game of five-card stud a clearly removed from the struggle outside, even though th SOUNDS of it are very close, coming through window openin on the alley. In fact the noise is so loud that the DEALE of the hand in progress reacts in annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody shut the goddam window. Let  a man think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player nearest the window shuts it. The Dealer, who a owns the restaurant, is the talkative type of poker playe Except for THE CINCINNATI KID, the other men at the table look like hoods of one sort or another: gunmen, labor spi extortionists, what have you. The man who fancies himself the toughest of them all is named DANNY, and he and The K have almost all the money on the table between them, abou hundred dollars in front of each. No other player has mor than a few dollars left, and now, as fifth cards are deal there is about forty dollars in the pot. Only four men ar left in the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible straight gets a -- (deals the card) -- lovely little four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the last hand even, you couldn't  give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put the brakes on your straight,  didn't I? (he laughs; no one  else does; he deals  to The Kid) There you are, son, a gorgeous deuce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deals to Danny) And our lucky friend from Chicago  gets a queen with his pair of sixes.  Little lady make you happy, Buster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal to yourself, clown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dealer gives himself a -- (deals card and groans) I might have known. (to Danny) Bet your sixes, Buster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to call me that. (then as the dealer  turns away) Cost you -- (counts out his money) Ninety-four bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biggest pot of the whole game, I got  to drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to First Player) Interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't call you if I had a pair  higher'n sixes. Which I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns over his cards, leaving it up to The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't seem like he'd bet out without  something better than the sixes,  does it? (fingers hole card as  if to fold) Cost me every cent I've won since  yesterday afternoon. (studies Danny's face) But I tell you, I got this stubborn  streak. Call the ninety-four dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He counts out the money, which is almost all he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) You can't have better than a pair of  kings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not claiming anything that  fine. (turns over an eight,  making a pair of  them) Just enough to beat the pair of sixes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen my hole card, you bastard! (indicating Dealer) He was dealing them high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attending to first things first, The Kid has been pulling the pot, adding it to his own stake, and pocketing the to Now as Danny accuses him again, The Kid looks him squarel in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stole that dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better watch those loose lips of  yours, you want to have any teeth  left behind them -- Buster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't of shelled out ninety- four bucks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called you on account of I didn't  think you had another pair or another  six and I know a punk like you would  get greedy and try and buy the last  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off, disappearing through a door marked "MEN."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is waiting when the door opens abruptly, and Danny app his right hand in his coat pocket. The Kid's hand goes to his own pocket and as he whirls around, a straight razor  appears in it, its blade snapped open. Pushing Danny to t wall with one hand, he keeps him pinned there with the ra in the other, while he bolts the door. Danny gets his rig hand out of the pocket with a gun in it, but The Kid move the razor blade against his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the gun clatters to the floor, and the others force th door, The Kid takes a step backward to provide enough  momentum, then swings at Danny's middle with his left,  dropping him, then jumps up on the wash basin and wriggle his way out through a window.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Danny recovers his balance and his gun, unbolts the door  just before it is smashed in, and runs with the others to get out of the building and after The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conflicting parties from the picket lines have moved The Kid drops from the window to the ground and starts to run toward the railroad yards. A few moments later, Danny and four other poker players appear and run after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chase across the tracks goes on behind the Credits. T Kid's pursuers split into two groups to cut him off, and  they seem to have succeeded in cornering him against a tr on which a passenger train is bearing down, headed for th station. His dubious chance of escape depends on his gett beyond this track in front of the train, which, with a bu of speed, he manages to accomplish just in time. The pass train divides The Kid from his pursuers, and we PAN with train into the depot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train slowly stops. Amid all the atmosphere of arriva in a day when the Pullman car was still the ultimate in  travel, LANCEY HODGES appears on a platform, takes his ba from the Pullman porter and passes it on to a Red Cap bef he has descended the steps. He walks with other passenger and Red Caps toward the center of the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting through the Meeting of the Rivers fountain acros Market Street to the Romanesque building with its campani

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey getting into a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey sits in serene repose in back, watching the sights by. The HACKIE steals a couple of looks at him in the rea vision mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you looking for, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to be looking for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can pretty much tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can pretty much tell what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guys come to town, I can tell  if they're looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I'm looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're looking for girls, I can  fix you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I strongly doubt if you could fix me  up. In that department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking for a clout in the  head if you don't keep your face to  the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doorman takes Lancey's suitcase as Lancey pays the Hack and walks into the hotel. A SECOND HACKIE whose cab is at the curb reacts to seeing Lancey and steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know who that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the second hackie has followed Lancey into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey crosses to the desk to register as the Second Hack goes to a row of phone booths and enters one. He dials wi his eyes on Lancey registering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Shorty? Want to hear who just checked  into the Park Sherman... Yes, you  do. Lancey Hodges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is talking on the phone while he hands out score sheet and shoes to some bowlers. He is just as excited by the r as the Hackie is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is talking on the telephone behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody sure as hell ought to tell  The Kid. (hangs up) Lancey Hodges is in town.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKING MAN
dialogues.text: He reacts to the news in a big way. CAMERA PANS to anothe DRINKING MAN, who is equally impressed. They exchange loo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid's been laying for him a long  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask me, The Kid'll go after him  as soon as he hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got a better right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the front room where the pool tables are. Throu an open door in b.g., we can see the unadvertised but  unconcealed other activity of the establishment: a poker  game in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to tell The Kid, Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I can't not tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's where he's been headed for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid enters the place through the front door, still a  little dishevelled from his escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in greeting) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you say, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hoban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been? Boys been holding a  chair for you in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business opportunity come along.  Something too good to pass up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn a profit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, did okay. Except I almost had  it took back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, one of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) You been in too many rough ones  lately, Kid. You can't go on forever,  coming out in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to build my stake, Aren't enough  chances in this town to let one go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too good, that's your trouble.  People who know you're the Cincinnati  Kid, they don't want to sit down  with you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For nickels and dimes... Thing is  I've about used up St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) The streets are getting full of guys  you've hustled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been thinking about Miami. There's  nothing to keep me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) The hell there isn't (as the Kid looks at  him) Lancey Hodges' in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? (then) The Man himself, here in St. Louis --  I might just stick around Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey is on the phone, sitting on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mr. Schlaegel? How are you? And your  enchanting wife?... Tomorrow is quite  convenient... I generally prefer  stud but you name it... Your stakes  are my pleasure, sir... Thank you,  why don't we make it after lunch? My  diet these days is enough to spoil  anyone else's appetite... A pleasure,  sir. Please remember me to your  charming wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and some of the strength seems to go out of h as if he had been through too long a sustained effort. Hi eyes show that he is feeling pain and he breathes deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold Street leads to the river and we follow The Kid an The Shooter as they walk down it in the gathering dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigar) I been seeing it coming for a long  time, Kid. Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't exactly been hiding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you ain't been hiding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I got to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you got to know. We all got to  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime or other we got to find out  how much juice we got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I had to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever sit down with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along, The Shooter pursing his lips thoughtfull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't lose. I'm too good to lose  when I set my mind to it. I play  poker a certain way, Kid. I've had  my Lancey Hodges. Only with me it  was Whistling Sam Magee to New  Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (respectfully) I heard about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then you know it all... about  20 years ago it was, maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I lost it. It dried me up on  the inside for a long, a very long  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been where I'm going, know what I  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid nods as they come to where an old wooden pier ext into the river. Along the river bank can be seen a small  portion of the mile-long Hooverville that stretches up an down the Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk out on the pier and eventually stop, look out a the river, watching the working boats. They have their  thoughts; The Shooter smoking his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after some time,  several seconds of  thoughtful puffing) Kid, I don't think you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not going to take my word  for it, are you? Are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I ain't. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. You got to find out  for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't figure to take him right  away. But if I can hang in there  long enough, I can outlast him. If I  can outlast him, I got a chance. You  admit that, don't you, that I got a  chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already said I didn't think you  were ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think you were ready when  you sat down with Whistling Sam Magee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, I thought I was the best stud  poker player in the world. I'm telling  you now, I thought I was the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I'm just a cocky  square with a fair hand with cards.  I got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you ain't no cocky square. And  you probably got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. And I ain't saying that you  was either when you sat down with  Whistling Sam Magee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got the stuff, being a little  cocky don't hurt you none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, would you say if I got any  chance at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much of a chance. If Lancey is  not right. If he's got a cold, or  his stomach ulcer is acting up, or  something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then everybody'd see he wasn't  right and it wouldn't prove nothing.  Listen, we got to have it understood.  If he's not right, we call it off  till he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're set on a real showdown, aren't  you? Your mind's all made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start back off the pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to. You said yourself I got  to. I'm overdue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you been around a long time --  I was a lot younger than you when I  went up against Whistling Sam -- But  you'd be kinda young too, to be The  Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Want me to set it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gratefully) I wish you would, Shooter Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what if he turns me down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't, the way I'll spread the  word. He'll have to take you on,  someone in your class. If he ducked  it, that'd make you The Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he knows I'm around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can smell meat like you a mile  and a half up the river. He knows  you're around and he'll sit down  with you. You want to butt heads  with The Man, I'll set it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, on the levee, CHRISTIAN is seen waiting for The Ki She has not yet seen them as they approach off the pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to wait around too  long. I want to get in and get it  over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must of come to St. Louis for a  big money game. I'll probably get  asked do I want to deal it for them.  And however long that takes, he'll  have to rest up for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, if he's tooling a dollar,  I can understand that. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got much of a stake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close to three grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work on it. But three grand will  give you a ride and even if you don't  win, why you'll come away with a  good idea of what you're made of.  But once you go in Kid you can't  quit. You get that straight right  now. Two of you go in and only one  of you can come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian sees them and moves toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, school's out. I damn sure don't  want no lessons. I want everything  he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only way to be, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooter turns away abruptly as Christian arrives, giving a brief nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid takes Christian's arm automatically; he watches T Shooter walk way down Harold Street. He and Christian hea in another direction. She is humming a mountain tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we leaving town, Kid? This week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't be ready. Not for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might even turn out we don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is surprised by this and, in her own hesitant way,  curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must feel different about it  than you did Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her fondly and, for one fleeting moment of  weakness, is actually tempted to tell her about Lancey. B it is too sharp a break with tradition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm feeling a little different. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is night and the room is lit only by a single lamp whe Christian sits in her nightgown on a chair by the window, turning over the pages of a mail-order catalogue. In f.g. The Kid lies on his back under a sheet on the bed, his ey closed and his hands clasped tensely behind his neck. He  opens his eyes and turns to look at her. The movement cat her eye, and she instantly stops turning the pages, afrai the noise has disturbed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. You don't have to  act like a cat. You're not bothering  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to turn out the light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm overtired, that's why I can't  sleep. (sits up and swings  his feet to the floor) Why can't you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) Undertired, I guess. If a person  rests all day, she doesn't have much  to rest up from at night. (stands up) Why don't you have a nice hot bath?  I could give you a rubdown and then  you could have a nice hot bath, and  then maybe you could sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits at the foot of the bed for him to come slowly t decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay. Can't hurt to try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes into the bathroom, where she turns the water on  gently so the tub will take a long while to fill. Then sh takes a bottle of alcohol from the medicine chest and ret to the bedroom with it. She stands in front of him waitin for him to move, but The Kid is singularly listless. Not  till she sets the bottle down does he respond by turning face to the pillow. She goes right to work on his shoulde muscles, and she seems to know what she is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do with yourself this  time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night I went to a movie with  The Shooter's woman. French movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had the words in English at the  bottom of the picture. But The  Shooter's woman knew what they were  saying without it. Pig's woman or  somebody told me she went to college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Majored in man-eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe she really did go. But  I never quite dared to up and ask  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you ran with The  Shooter's woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to be kind of friendly when  you both were in that three-day game  down to Cairo. 'Course she's older'n  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And been around more. A lot more.  What was the movie like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird. It wasn't a straight story  where you knew whose side you were  on, the way you do in regular  pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. There were lots of things I  didn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's this town in Europe a  long time ago where they get a message  from a Spanish general he's coming  to spend the night with his troops.  So all the men are scared silly about  what the soldiers will do to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing weird about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all the wives and daughters tell  the men to go hide somewhere and let  them bargain with the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't make much sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. The way they handle it is they  go to bed with the Spaniards. And  the next morning the soldiers go off  peacefully and everybody's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including the husbands and fathers?  Don't they suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's part of what I wasn't sure  of. I guess they know what went on  but they care more about their safety  and their money than they do about  their honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they got their heads screwed on  straight. Honor's just an idea. You  can't see or feel it and you can't  eat it and you sure as hell can't  get any mileage on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slaps him on the rump and straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just turn off the bath water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't move but just stays relaxed and closes his eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian, humming softly, turns off the water, takes a l towel from a rack and puts it on a stool by the tub where will be more convenient for him. She lingers to test the  water with her finger and do anything else she can think to assure maximum comfort for her man. Then she steps bac into the bedroom. The sight of him makes her advance  cautiously and confirm her suspicion that he is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MELBA, The Shooter's woman, is sitting up in bed working her eyebrows and listening to MUSIC turned up LOUD on a r The bedside phone RINGS, barely audible above the radio. answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Yes, it is. You want him? (calling) Shooter! Telephone! Shooter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets no answer, which is no wonder in view of the noi from the radio. But the radio is across the room and it's slightly easier for her to get out of the side of the bed she's on, and go to the door of The Shooter's room. She o this and we see The Shooter in bed in his own small quart reading a magazine. He turns around inquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone for you. I always seem to be  the one to answer it, no matter who  it's for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) If you'd rather we put it in my room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter picks up the phone but before he speaks into he pantomimes to her that he won't be able to hear over t radio. She seems to regard the request as an imposition b she does go grudgingly to the radio and turns it down a l before she returns to her bed and her cosmetic chore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?... Well, hello. What brings  you to our fair city? Little action,  maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey, dressed for bed, is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) How could you guess, Shooter? I was  invited by a Mr. William Schlaegel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Owns most of the Schlaegel Brewery.  Braumeister beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter sits down on the edge of Melba's bed, the mov jostling her so she pricks herself with her tweezers. She exclaims in protest and gives him a dirty look that makes The Shooter stand right up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) As he put it, rather bluntly, I felt,  we don't want everyone to have to  watch everyone else dealing to see  to it they don't make any little  accidental errors by mistake. I told  him a man couldn't ask for a better  guarantee of a fair-and-square game  than having The Shooter deal it. So  if you're willing, we're meeting at  two o'clock in the afternoon. Ask  for Mr. Schlaegel's suite at the  Park Sherman... Good. I'm glad you  can do it, Shooter. Be a pleasure to  see you again... (then) Oh pretty much the same... Just have  to be a little careful about smoking  and drinking and eating -- and  breathing. See you tomorrow. Good  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone, settles himself in a comfortable c and opens a heavy book. CAMERA MOVES in CLOSE enough to r the title: Prescott's CONQUEST OF PERU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is midday outside but the window shades are tightly dr to keep the daylight from disturbing The Kid, who is stil asleep. Christian, dressed for the street, moves from the bedroom to the kitchen-living room which is the remainder the two-room apartment. Finding paper and pencil, she wri a quick note and leaves it on the kitchen table, then sta out. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring one bathing suit displayed among others in an e of-season sale with some such advertising message as "All bathing suits reduced 1/3 for clearance!" The particular  suit is a two-piece one, exposing two or three inches of  bare midriff -- the first modest forerunner of the trend  that led eventually to the bikini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you wear it in public?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Christian and Melba looking the display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be much point wearing it in  private. Sure, why not, as long as  you don't have a bulge to hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Melba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking her over) My guess is there isn't anything  about you needs hiding. But I'll  give you a more definitive opinion  at the bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) At the what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkish Bath. After we're through  shopping. I'm treating you, Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never been. I'm not even sure what  you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't do anything. That's what's  so marvelous. They do it to you. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA finds Christian and Melba among the perspiring fem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third time I stayed. Never went  back to the boarding house except to  pick up my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that side of it's held up? No  complaints in the bed department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nights he isn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really does that to you, does he?  You got one of the rare ones. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian and Melba are on adjoining rubbing tables, a cu separating them from the waist down only. Their heads are close enough so they can talk without their masseurs  necessarily hearing every word they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find a guy, you love him, and  that's it. It's supposed to just go  on like that for life. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the propaganda, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it isn't my life, it's his life,  with me tacked on. You have any idea  what it's like to be a hash slinger  in a cheap restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, the stock crash wafted me  right from the daisy chain into  unmarried bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hell, if you'll excuse the word.  But I didn't want to quit. The Kid  made me. I felt I ought to hang on  to something that was me away from  him. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Some girls solve the problem  by taking on an extra guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Having children might  take care of it, I don't know. Or --  this is really a terrible thing to  admit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your most sordid secrets are safe  with me. Confess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he was rich, or famous --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you give him both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why not? Well, if he was rich and  famous, maybe I wouldn't mind so  much just being -- just a woman to  him. Do you think that might make it  seem more worthwhile somehow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow! Are you sincere, sweetie? (reacting to the  masseur's touch) Oooo -- divine. (to Christian) Isn't this heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. In a way it seems soft  of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is at a loss for a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decadent? Depraved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian looks blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wicked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I meant by heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey, Shooter and five other men are sitting in comfort padded chairs around a well-appointed poker table. Everyt about the game is in sharp contrast to the one The Kid pl in. It is played with chips - expensive ones; there are a couple of bottles of wine on ice, fine cigars, a tray of  sandwiches, etc. Lancey's opponents are all wealthy types two of them could be Texas oil men. The youngest, a good- looking man of thirty, is BILL SCHLAEGEL. The Shooter, as nonplaying dealer, distributes fifth cards to the four  remaining players in the hand, and both Lancey and Bill e up with four cards of one suit showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he deals) Still queens -- possible flush -- no  help -- possible flush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queens check to the possibles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill silently tosses in two of the rarest and highest ran chips on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And up two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biggest pot yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone RINGS and the Third Wealthy Type answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the two thou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning over queen  of his suit) Queen high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Jack high. Can you beat that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Second Wealthy  Type) It's your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas or Tulsa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just said office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Third Wealthy Type takes the phone and speaks on it d the ensuing. The Second Wealthy Type crosses to the bar a fixes himself a drink. Lancey takes in his winnings. Bill hasn't recovered from the blow. There is a hiatus in the  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the bloody hell did you figure  out I didn't have the king or the  ace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recollect a young fellow putting  the same question to Eddie the Dude.  It was a game in the grand lounge of  the "J.M. White, Third," the largest  paddle-wheeler ever built. "Son,"  Eddie told him, "All you paid was  the looking price. Lessons are extra." (turns to Shooter) First time I heard of this Cincinnati  Kid was in New Orleans, at Yeller's.  I knew right away I'd have to play  him someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll enjoy his game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may admire it. But if he's all  that good, I doubt if I'll enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tougher the competition, the  better you used to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've learned to take everything in  moderation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early evening. The Kid approaches the restaurant wi Christian on one arm, Melba on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melba) Have a drink with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better not. Shooter said they'd break  at seven, and he has to have his  food first, then his nap. (looking The Kid over) You know, there's a day in your life  I'm looking forward to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day The Kid becomes The Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at them both and goes off. They move to enter restaurant. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plates with the remains of their main course are in f of them. The Kid pours what's left of a bottle of beer in his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you sleep Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I slept okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind my not being  there when you woke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't mind -- (then) What she was talking about, Shooter's  woman -- I'm going up against a big  game soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me. It's a very big game, I  hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it be long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? (then) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd go home and see Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be able to spare you much  change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't want much. Bus is  really the best way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would a hundred fish do it? For the  bus and something nice to bring your  Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be fine, Kid. Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When would you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason for not going right  now unless --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lowers her eyes, finding it hard to say the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you wanted to go to bed first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to? Would you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un-huh. I'd like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want dessert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks o.s. raising a hand to summon the check. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark in the room and dark outside, the street lamps furnishing only enough light for a faint border around th window shade. Christian's head and nude back move into th Shot; she pulls the shade aside to look out.

dialogues.speaker: ILLUMINATED CLOCK
dialogues.text: The time is a few minutes before ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets the shade fall back into place. Moving quietly i the darkness, she begins to dress. CAMERA PULLS BACK and  PANS to include The Kid, lying on the bed with a sheet ov him. He seems to be asleep until he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still haven't said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian abandons the process of dressing herself and si down in the easy chair to answer this question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I ought to stay with Mama and  Papa a while, and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did like city streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. The promise didn't fulfill  itself for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to the city and all. Electric  lights and flush toilets. All the  pretty dreams -- it was all promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you do or not Kid --  You're city -- and I'm country --  You grew up with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's why you're going --  because you like it so much better  in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't comment one way or the other, nor does he pre the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got that big game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he's The Man for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. If I won, there would be a lot  of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll win. You been coming on strong  a long way. This is your time. (then after a long  moment) Come home with me to Mama's Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) I know you are honey -- I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and begins to pack her clothes in an old suit After a moment The Kid gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go down to the bus with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to dress) I'll go down with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Kid --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to sound kind of funny  to you, but I want to ask it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think there's any chance, if  you do win this big game, that you  might do something else besides cards? (hastily) I don't mean never play poker. I  just mean not have it be the only  thing you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, it's the only thing I know how  to do. What else is there for a guy  never finished school? College  graduates are walking the streets  looking for jobs -- trained people,  engineers, scientists!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not letting her speak) When you're The Man, you don't have  to hustle -- When you're The Man,  The Best, the Big Money comes around  on their knees just beggin' to hustle  you. I'm not goin' to quit. I'm goin'  to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I can see that. Of course I  didn't say quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you see how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Christian, you aren't doing this to  be off my back, in case I lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinking about it a long time.  I been planning to go home and see  how I felt about things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this just helped you decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) No, this is your time -- Now you go  on Honey and you play The Man --  I'll be at Mama's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the suitcase and puts on the one dress she has packed. The Kid, dressed now, watches her for a moment th goes to the bottom drawer of the dresser and opens it to  reveal a stack of money under a shirt. He takes five clea twenty-dollar bills and counts them on to the top of the  dresser, snapping the crisp leaves gambler style. Then he stoops down again and takes out two more twenties, adding them to the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it could be more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't actually hand her the money. He leaves it on t of the dresser and she goes over and takes it, folding th bills and putting them in her change purse. The Kid picks her suitcase, and she leads the way into the other room. the front door she stops and looks back at the little  apartment for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't guess I'll ever forget these  rooms, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't guess I will either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I win, it won't be good enough.  If I lose, I lose it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him for a moment, then exits. He follows. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid and Christian sit in silence. She puts her hand o his. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid and Christian sit on a bench in the waiting room, still silent. He has her suitcase between his legs and a  pile of magazines on his lap. She looks at a clock and ge to her feet. He follows her to the door, carrying the sui and magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian boards a bus that has seen better days. On the  steps she turns to take the bag from him, but he follows on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian takes a seat. The Kid puts her suitcase in the  overhead rack and hands her the magazines, none of which  would be classed as heavy reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Kid. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't kiss. He turns and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are not many passengers boarding this bus. After a  couple of moments, the driver closes the door and starts  off. Christian waves from the window, and The Kid waves b to her. When the bus has gone, he walks around the outsid of the terminal to the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a couple of cabs at a taxi stand. One of the ha offers his services to The Kid, but The Kid declines. He  wants to walk. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is midday and the poker game is almost twenty- four ho old. Our attention is focused on Bill Schlaegel, who is  writing out a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four stacks? Right, Schooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter takes advantage of the lull in the proceeding to move to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the entertainment,  gentlemen. My particular gratitude  to you, Lancey. It's been a rare  pleasure to watch a great artist at  work. Thank you for the privilege.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey gives him a quick look, finding this a bit thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, son, you're quite welcome.  Can't say I recall another man, in  all my days on the three rivers, who  seemed to find it quite so pleasurable  losing all that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill puts his check down in front of The Shooter's place, and gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, gentlemen. You're welcome  to use the premises as long as you  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES with Bill as he passes The Shooter, who is  waiting on the phone while the hotel operator dials his  number. Bill gives him a friendly pat on the back, and sp in a low, harsh voice for The Shooter's ears alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill goes out. Shooter looks after him as his party comes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, Kid. Shooter here. Listen, I  told the woman I'd take her to the  ball park, but I'm still working.  How about you and Christian take her  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Christian's gone home to see her  folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Oh. (then) Well listen, would you mind taking  her yourself? The gang'll be there,  in the section... Thanks. Appreciate  it. See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, returns to the table and starts to shuffle t cards in his own spectacular way. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is in progress between the Cardinals and another  National League club. The batter at the plate connects fo long one. CAMERA FOLLOWS the flight of the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are making their way to meet their friends in the se they prefer. They stop to watch the ball as the fans arou them rise to their feet. The section they have just reach is in the sun, overlooking the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outfielder races back and makes a difficult catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start on their way again. CAMERA PANS ahead of them a group consisting of Hoban; HOBAN'S WOMAN, still sexy in her forties; PIG, whose name could derive with equal  justification from either his looks or his manners; and S who talks colloquial American with a Central European acc The group as a whole is notable because its members have risen to their feet with everyone else, because all the m are basking in the sun with their shirts off, because the view the action on the field with detachment, and because nevertheless, they are constantly placing bets on details the game. Now, as people around them resume their seats,  Sokal is able to confirm that the fly ball has been caugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hoban) You owe me two fish on the out, plus  three on the inning, minus two on no  strikeouts so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid and Melba join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Kid. Getting yourself in shape  for The Man? (to Melba) Shooter still on the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Christian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Lay off that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she do, take off? So did mine.  Don't lose no sweat, Kid, there's  plenty more where they came from.  All shapes and sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Hoban. Sokal. Pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Melba sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sokal) Boyer. One to two on the sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five to three, I'll give you. Two- fifty against one-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure they'll walk him. Fill up  first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with who's coming up. I'll take  the same odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he is talking, Melba unbuttons his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some of this sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to The Kid) Mark it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melba) Guess I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his shirt off. Melba finds some suntan lotion in her bag, and applies it to her face and arms, her eyes ra straying from The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunting, Sokal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bunt is fielded by the first baseman, who throws to s for the out. There is no play at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they pitched to him. I still win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kid) Everybody been on the phone to  everybody about coming to watch you  and Lancey. Big Spriigi, Yeller to  N'Orleans, Old Lady Fingers. They're  all coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kid) Let me give you some of this. Keep  you from burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without waiting for his approval, she goes ahead and spre the lotion on his skin, painstakingly, as if she were app paint to canvas, working it in, one area at a time, with fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sokal) Chance to invest your profits. Bet  you an even fin he make first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking toward plate) Who we got -- Warwick? You got  yourself a bet, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men concentrate their attention on the diamond. CAMER MOVES IN to Melba's fingers playing across The Kid's midr From the field comes the sharp CRACK of a bat against a b followed by a SHOUT from the crowd. CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of Melba and The Kid as he looks at her and she mee his gaze with inviting eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your day, Hoban. (calling to a vendor) Hey, beer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Mais tu es charmant --

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: With the same look of invitation in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charmant. Come here, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK. Wearing the same clothes as at the bal park, she is sitting in a chair with her legs tucked unde her. The Kid is sitting on a straight chair at a table on which he has a cup of coffee. They are alone in the apart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any special reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. I'm special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up but doesn't move toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you are. You're The Shooter's  woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And maybe I'll go on being  The Shooter's Woman, even after you  and I have had our little romp. What  do you think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First place, Old Shooter'll come  barging through that door any minute.  He said they were winding it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No barging. He doesn't have his key  with him. (stands up) Have to buzz from downstairs. (moves toward him  provocatively) So we can treat ourselves to a little  sample of things to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid stays where he is as she comes up against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also it don't mean anything to you,  you're Christian's friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, she lost her franchise the  minute she got on that bus. You know  that. (her arms around him) I have a shaky sense of security,  Kid. Don't make me feel unwanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her and lets himself enjoy it for a while, then pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know damn well how good it was.  Where's a pack of cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we need cards for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin or casino, you name it. All I  know is we're switching to another  indoor sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poker game is over. Two of the Wealthy Types have alr departed; one is finishing a drink on the way out; anothe is putting his winnings into his wallet; a third is writi out a check. Lancey and The Shooter still sit at the tabl in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers'll want to come, I bet,  and she's right on the edge of her  stake. She could spell me dealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Haven't seen the dear  old bitch in fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's it, then. Monday night,  Room Three-Eleven at the Dorset Hotel.  And may the best man win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's how it usually comes out  in the long run. You think this boy  is going to give me trouble, Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's going to give you trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it to be one of those  marathon games. Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the session with The Portugee  at Jolly's in Omaha. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Longest game I ever played  though, I was a kid on my way to the  Klondike gold rush. At Soapy Smith's  in Skagway. Four nights and three  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends how you look at it. When we  wound up, the Yukon River had frozen  over and you couldn't get through to  Dawson City till the following June.  Made myself a Hundred and fifty bucks  and missed the gold rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been around a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is undeniably true. But it  doesn't mean I'm ready to retire.  How old is this boy of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six, twenty-eight, something  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, makes me feel a whole lot  better, knowing that. I was thirty- six when I sliced up Eddie the Dude.  This Kid of yours is just going to  have to wait a few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is standing by an elevator in f.g. keeping watch on a of room doors including the site of the poker game. FELIX an impressive physical specimen whose capacity for brutal is masked by a quiet, deferential manner. When he sees a  door open, he moves so as to be out of The Shooter's sigh as the latter comes toward him. It isn't until The Shoote rounds the corner in f.g. and presses the button for the  elevator that Felix makes his presence known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Shooter, sir, but Mr.  Schlaegel asked me to remind you how  eager he was to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors of the elevator open. Felix yields precedence t The Shooter and they enter it. The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elevator opens, and The Shooter and Felix come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to call my woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. They always like to  know it if you're going to be late  for supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES with them as The Shooter leads the way to a of telephone booths and enters one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sitting at the table in a game of casino. She pl an ace from her hand, adds a seven from the board, and la them both on top of a three-card pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still building eights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for putting it together for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays an eight and takes in the whole pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone RINGS. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to know what is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS her to the phone. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello -- Oh, hi, sugar -- why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches a hand around to the back of her neck, fiddle with her dress a moment, then beckons in The Kid's direct

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He doesn't understand what she wants but he gets up and c to her obligingly, CAMERA MOVING with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) What's the switch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to the hook-and-eye fastener at the top of the zipper that runs down the back of her dress. The Kid  pantomimes the question "What for?" but she just wiggles finger impatiently at the fastener while speaking into th phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Whose idea was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid still doesn't know what she has in mind but it se easier to humor her than not. He unfastens the hook. Melb smiles her thanks and, to his consternation, reaches back and pulls the zipper all the way down. She places her han over the mouth-piece of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kid) He's not coming home now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps out of the dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Whatever you say, Shooter man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Explain to The Kid, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melba in her bra and panties, snuggles against The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) He'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Tell him they decided to play a little  longer, and I'll call him at his  place later when the game's over...  Right. Goodbye, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone and emerges from the booth. CAMERA  MOVES with him as he joins Felix and they walk toward the hotel entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid, his policy toward this new situation still  unresolved, holds her lightly while he tries to think it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Melba --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you first. You're  sitting down with Lancey next Monday  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it was sooner. I wish it was  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooter'll give you all the details  later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like waiting that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not kick a gift horse in the  teeth, sugar. We've got this time  together. Let's try to "fill each  unforgiving minute with sixty seconds  worth of distance run."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She invites a kiss and he obliges her. But there is a con force at work inside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, what I was going to say  before, I don't want you to think  I'm being some kind of jerk or I  don't feel you'd be great to sack up  with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's cut the filibuster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made dolls that were friends of  mine's wives. I figured if they were  willing, they were doing it to their  husbands, I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Any other attitude, you're  degrading the woman. You're not  treating her as a person with a mind  of her own, but as somebody's  property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again she presses close to him and again he savors her fo moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only thing is, it's different with  The Shooter than anybody else. He's  so straight, I got the obligation to  be straighter with him than other  people. So do you. On account of we  both owe him plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we just agreed that what  you and I did was strictly between  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be. (decisively, pulling  away from her with a  pat of dismissal) Shooter's the closest thing to family  I got. It's almost like he was my  old man. Don't you see how that's  got a bearing on us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out. Melba stares after him, scarcely able to  believe what is being done to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it means I'm your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expensive automobile, with Felix at the wheel and The  Shooter next to him in the front seat, approaches the mai house of a lavish estate in a St. Louis suburb. It contin along the driveway past the house.

dialogues.speaker: BILL AND BABY
dialogues.text: In swimming trunks, Bill is spoon-feeding a year-old BABY a highchair. Looking o.s., he waves in greeting to The  Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks from the parked car toward the pool, returning B salutation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING from behind The Shooter as he approaches the  attractive family group that includes, besides Bill and t baby, a FIVE-YEAR-OLD GIRL who is having her hair brushed after swimming by ROSANNA SCHLAEGEL, her beautiful mother family dog completes the picture. Bill continues to feed baby as he hails The Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooter -- very generous of you to  come on such short notice. Rosanna  you know, and I think you've met my  daughter June. (indicating baby) No point introducing you to William  the Fourth. He has a bad memory for  names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greeting them in  turn) Mrs. Schlaegel. How are you, June.  What's it all about, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little something I'd like to sound  you out on. But the least I can do  is offer you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like me to fix it, love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. Why don't you do a batch  of your Bloody Marys? If that's okay  with you, Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she goes off, Rosanna cautions June about her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't let it get wet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as his wife is gone, Bill goes right to the topic doesn't want to discuss in her presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been quite busy on the telephone  since I last saw you. There's a lot  of interest all over the country in  this game with Lancey and The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betting interest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Doyle in New York is giving  twelve to five on Lancey. Same odds  in Reno. I've taken fifty thousand  of it so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll probably go for more but I didn't  want to rock the odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you liked The Kid's style but  why you going in so deep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two reasons. First, I want to see  that smug old bastard gutted worse  than he gutted me. Second, as long  as that's going to happen, I don't  see why I shouldn't make some money  out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how can you be so sure? The Kid  could do it, we both know that, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Could" isn't good enough for a man  who hates to lose money as much as I  do. He's going to need help -- from  the best man with a pack of cards  between Omaha and New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance, Bill. You ought to  know I never ever use what I got  with the cards for nothing but tricks  and dressing up a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I know it. That's why you're  the man they choose to give them a  square deal. That's what makes it so  perfect. Nobody'll be looking for  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out. Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great thing is they'll be so  close, The Kid won't need much. Three  or four key hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand this, Bill. I'd like for  The Kid to win, and I sure as hell  don't want to see you lose all that  money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did, I'd have to collect that  twelve grand you owe me. Not myself.  My collection agents. You knew poor  Wildwood Jones, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK but I'm paying it off! It's comin'  in ain't it? Six grand already. (then as Bill just  looks at him) Bill, you got to listen to me --!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't. It's quite the other  way around. You have some delusion  you're a free agent, but you're not.  I own you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake --!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I'll cross the twelve off  the books and give you ten thousand  dollars in cash. And you can tell  The Kid if he needs more of a stake,  I'll put it up. (looks o.s. and smiles) Marvelous. Here's Rosanna with what  you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES to include Rosanna carrying a tray with glas and a pitcher full of Bloody Marys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- for that dry feeling on the roof  of your mouth. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: It is raining dismally.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He is lying on one half of the bed, with the covers throw back, his hands clasped behind his head, wearing pajama  bottoms. He turns his head and stares at the white expans of unoccupied bed. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather is clear as The Kid wanders idly along a  residential street of well-kept nineteenth century buildi (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is drinking a bottle of beer slowly. CAMERA PANS to an bar stool where a customer is having his shoes shined by NEGRO BOY who slaps his rag against the shoes with a fine sense of rhythm. Finished, he collects his dime and nicke tip, and moves to The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shine them up for you sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch you a newspaper maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a singy-song then? I play  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy takes out a tobacco can with the lid torn off and the top flattened down and shakes it, producing a sound l the rustle of dry leaves. Then he produces a similar can  that makes a rattling noise when he shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dry corn in this one. Blue shale  stone from the river in this one.  You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy looks at the BARTENDER, who has moved closer to s what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bartender) You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I'm ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy stands perfectly still for a few seconds, then be to shake the can with corn in it. After a bit he brings i the shale stone can with the other hand to chord and acce the rustle of the first can. At the same time he begins to sing a simple song in a pur delicate voice. It is catfish music created on the spot a sounds strangely like the idle tunes Christian likes to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (when the song is  over) Thank you very much. That was nice.  Where did you learn to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I picked it up from Herman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Herman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend I pick it up from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a good friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know 'bout that suh. He just  a frien' who teach me some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want a shine, but here's  fifteen cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's another dime for you,  fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rings up a NO SALE and flips a dime to The Boy, who is astonished and then worried by this munificence. Suddenly grabs his tobacco cans and his shoe-shine kit, and runs o into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice little colored kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mostly to himself) -- Yeah. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANSEN, a masseur, is at work loosening up The Kid's neck and shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday night, uh, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sprung for some of the action. A  yard and a half of that five-to-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jansen. (in pain) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to get you loosened up. I  never felt you this tight. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in the middle of a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Just tell The Shooter I'll be there  on the dot Monday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the phone) And until then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'm not asking for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone, rather than continue the discussio CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he comes out of the booth, picks up small duffel bag, and walks to the door that leads to the busses. He goes out into the night and gets into a bus. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus drives along a main road in the Ozarks, heading tow CAMERA. As it comes close, the name of its destination:  "FAYETTEVILLE" can be read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops momentarily at a small cluster of buildings around an intersection. The Kid is the only passenger to off here. As the bus continues on its way, he goes to an  attendant in a gas station on one corner, and asks a ques Referred to a general store and post office on another co he crosses and goes into it. The STOREKEEPER comes back  outside with him to point out the route to where he wants go. It is along a dirt road that winds uphill behind the  store. The Kid starts up the road. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid reaches the summit of the hill directly behind th crossroads, and looks down into the valley between this h and the next one. He starts down an even narrower road le to a little farm on a hillock in the valley. It consists a modest cabin, a single barn, a fenced cow pasture, and few cultivated fields. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian comes around a curve in a path on one side of t house, carrying two five-gallon milk cans slung in a yoke over her shoulder. A little dog YAPS and runs from the fr door of the house to the front gate. She looks in that  direction and CAMERA MOVES to include The Kid as he unlat the gate and walks toward her. After a moment's hesitatio she moves to meet him, gliding on her bare feet to keep t water in the cans from slopping out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you with those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking if off is harder than taking  it on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns toward the side of the house and walks to the  kitchen door. The Kid follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's The Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't played yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. CRAIGIE, Christian's mother, opens the door for them giving The Kid a sharp, appraising glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Eric, Mama. He's come to see  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian crosses to the drain sink near the pump and tur her back. Mrs. Craigie lifts the cans off the yoke on to drain board. She and Christian each take a can and pour t water from it to prime the pump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost suction on the pump right in  the middle of canning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid looks at the stove with a couple of large steamin pots on it, and the table alongside with a half-dozen ham of green beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's coffee. And sour ham and  bread in the warmer, if you're hungry  Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as they are finished with the pump, Mrs. Craigie Christian turn to the table, where they begin to snip ste and cut beans before putting them into the pots on the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know anything about canning, you  know we can't stop now. If we'd been  looking for company, we never would  have started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring beans, you have to cook them  fast. But you find yourself some  breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right. Bus stopped for  doughnuts and coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
