dialogues.text: You can stay with us tonight and  still make it back to St. Lou on the  Sunday schedule by about midnight. I  told Mama and Papa about The Man.  And all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Mr. Craigie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the barn. Why don't you go down  and introduce yourself? Christian  and me'll be at this another hour or  two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I will. I think I'd like  that. (to Christian) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. And I'll see you a little later  on. (then, as he starts  out) Papa don't know everything. About  you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid looks quickly at her and then at Mrs. Craigie, wh keeps her gaze fixed on the beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pitching manure from all over the cow-lot into a pi banked against the side of the barn, working a long-handl shovel with practised ease. He looks o.s. and sees The Ki approaching but continues his work as The Kid enters the  SHOT. Nor does he stop shoveling while they are talking,  except at moments of particular significance to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Craigie. I'm Eric  Stoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian's Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's helping her mother can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You minding to marry Christian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid looks at him a long moment then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any objections if I do, or  if I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craigie takes a couple of steps toward The Kid, his boots sucking in the muddy ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, that's what I call a sharp  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was what I call a sharp question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know much about you,  Christian's mother and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm what's known as a three-river  man. Which just means I go around  playing stud poker wherever I can  find the kind of action I'm looking  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met Christian when she was working  to Hot Springs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was playing in this game in  the hotel and she was a waitress in  the coffee shop. We went out. I told  her I thought she could get a better  job in St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now how did you happen to tell her  that? Maybe you run some kind of  employment service on the side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it because I wanted her in  St. Louis. Anyway, she made it there  and she called me and we been seeing  each other ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid takes his time before deciding how to answer this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, living together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come she come home now? She going  to have a baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two have a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have had a reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think so? Well, you've known her  longer than me. (then) Look, Mr. Craigie, let me and  Christian find out a few things then  maybe I won't have to answer your  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never run across anybody like you.  I guess I don't understand gamblers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. I don't understand  farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say things that sound smart  alecky. But I'm not sure if they  really are smart alecky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I can't take into account what  somebody's going to feel every time  I say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a believer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean in God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a tough one. I don't disbelieve  in Him, but I couldn't say I believed  in Him either. I guess I just never  paid Him much mind. Didn't seem  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God not important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean what He does isn't  important -- if He exists. I mean  it's not important to me whether He  exists or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian was raised in a Christian  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? I didn't know --- (then) I'm not aware of the difference. (pause) I'm not asking permission to marry  Christian, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was, the only person I'd be  asking it from is her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Who is this fella Christian says  you're going to play that's so  important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the king of the stud poker  players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're going to play him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm this good. The Man has got to  play me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if he don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm The Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That important to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been trying to figure that out  ever since I set it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You playing because of money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian said you never was much  worried about money -- I been worried  about money most of my life -- up  until I figured out it wasn't so  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's necessary, but it isn't so  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well how come you want to play this  King fella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambition -- maybe security, like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it aspiration to be the King or  just uncertainty about the future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't looking for security if that's  what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not trying to lock something up tight  and nail it down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would figure into it. But that  isn't all of it. -- It's important  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now son which is more important to  you, this king business or Christian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got the guts to ask that  question, Mr. Craigie, I guess I got  the guts to answer it. Christian, if  you came right down to it, is not as  important as doing what I have to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craigie has finished piling the manure. He puts away his  shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well son, I had to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There never was a man worth a damn,  to my mind, who let his woman stand  in the way of the thing he had to  do. (then) I got to go now -- see what I can do  for a sick heifer. Why don't you  take Christian, when her Mama lets  go of her, and tell her I said you  should go to the old spring. It's a  good place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craigie walks away. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SPRING
dialogues.text: It is a small shack against a rocky bluff. CAMERA PANS  Christian and The Kid as they come down the path and ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stays warm all winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES to reveal Christian and The Kid, who are in pool without clothes, treading water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa's mama used to bring her wash  up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We liable to draw an audience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's on our land --  Nobody uses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to swim, CAMERA MOVING with her upper back as reaches the side of the pool and pulls herself on to the  bank, lying on her stomach. The Kid joins her, first draw himself up on his stomach alongside her, then turning on back to look through the slats at the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have said something to Papa  gave him the picture on us in St.  Lou. Else he never would have spoke  to you about this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him on account of he already  knew. Never any sense feeding a man  a lie he's not going to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if he did know, I'm glad you  told him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises herself up so that she is directly above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in mock protest) Hey, you're all wet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you, foolish. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are sitting just outside the kitchen, where M Craigie and Christian are pasting labels on the mason jar they filled earlier. The paste and some of the jars are j inside an open window on a shelf behind the men's heads. light comes from a kerosene lamp inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight in my head.  Cards is all a matter of luck, who  gets dealt the best ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid stands up and selects six playing cards from a de in his pocket. During the next few lines he uses the past on the shelf to stick together three pairs of them so as form three double-thick cards. One of these has two faces another two backs, and the third a back and a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when one of you professional  gamblers sits down with a bunch of  your -- what do you call them --  customers, clients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technical term is "suckers." Or  "marks."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their chance of winning is just as  good as yours, except if you got a  way to control it, who gets what  cards. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right. That's cheating and it's  not any part of what we're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He displays his three cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see one of these cards is white  on both sides, one is red on both  sides, and the other is white on one  side, red on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid lifts a straw hat off a peg on the porch wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This. I put the three cards in a hat  and shake them up, and then I ask  you to draw one card out blind. Put  it face down on the table so neither  of us can see the bottom side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craigie does as instructed. The ensuing dialogue assumes card he picks is red on top; if it's white the words "red and "white" will be reversed in the dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, red on top. That eliminates  the all-white card, right. So the  card you've picked is one of two --  the all-red or the red-and-white.  One out of two is an even chance, an  even-money proposition. Right -- you  follow me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I said I'll bet you a dollar  to seventy-five cents the other side  of that card is red, you'd take the  bet wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that answer makes you a sucker.  Because the odds are two to one, the  other side of that card is red, and  I ought to be offering you a dollar  to fifty cents instead of seventy- five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if there are just the two  possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three possibilities. (indicating card on  table) That can be the red side of the red- and-white card, or it can be either  side of the all-red card. In two  cases out of three the other side is  red. And I'd win the bet from you  two out of every three times we made  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously) You would?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's obvious when I explain  it, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon so. Except if there's only  two things that the bottom side can  be, red or white --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my word for it -- the odds are  two to one. And knowing that is the  difference between your gambling man  and your sucker. Not who gets the  better cards but who knows what the  proper odds are. In a poker game  there can be a million different  situations, each with a different  set of odds to figure. The man who  ends up winners is the man who knows  when to bet and how much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sucker is still took advantage  of, isn't he? The gambler knows  something he don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- like if you grow better corn  or raise a cow that gives more milk  than the other guy's. Or two business  men are in competition, or two lawyers  are up against each other in a  courtroom. Whatever your line is,  the one who wins out is the one who  knows his job better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like there should be something  else to it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is -- Making the man you're  playing against think he's got the  best hand -- and making him pay to  find out. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is lying on a cot in the darkness, next to the big woo burning stove. Christian enters the SHOT and slips under covers with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay long. Papa'll be getting  up to milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one can't stay. I got to  head for that bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, I don't know. I had kind  of a rough time after you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday there was a ball game, but  then the Cardinals went on the road.  I never known time to drag so; I was  all torn apart --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the poker game coming up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I read it, but I was  reading it wrong. It wasn't Lancey  or the game that was chewing at my  insides --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else is there could give you  such a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally figured it. I located where  the trouble was. It was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is genuinely surprised at this and at first a bit  dismayed. But her more considered reaction is one of plea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you talk about doing something  besides poker if I get to be The  Man, you don't mean pass up the chance  to make some dough from it for a  while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure don't. I told Papa, wherever  money comes from, it feels the same  when you spend it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were going to do some thinking  down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I done some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they both react as Craigie can be heard getting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back after the game Christian --  You wait here for me and I'll let  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Eric -- Good luck Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a quick kiss and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got that made now. You said it  right. My time's come. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun hasn't risen yet as The Kid boards the bus for St Louis outside the general store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid's bus crossing the endless plain in the afternoon sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock above the loading platform says it is a little  after two in the morning as the bus pulls up, and The Kid groggy from the long ride, gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters wearily, goes straight into the bedroom and  collapses on the bed. After a moment he summons the energ to loosen his shoelaces and kick his shoes off. But that  completes his preparations for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter is awake because he can't sleep, and Melba is awake because she is trying to persuade him to do what sh considers prudent. He sighs deeply as she solicitously po him a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five years I been building a  reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handle this thing right and your  reputation will be better than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey is also awake, confronting a row of medicine bottl He finishes laying out an assortment of four different pi and capsules, pours himself a glass of hot milk from a ca and proceeds to take the pills one at a time, with a sip milk after each. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid, looking completely refreshed, is readying himsel for the game. He has chosen casual, comfortable clothes, now he collects three items to take with him: a large bot of mouthwash, a green sun-vizor, and finally, his stake.  When he withdraws the money from the dresser drawer, we c see the pile has increased in size. The Kid finds an enve to put it in, and he is ready to go. He starts out but in the middle of the kitchen he stops to look at his watch. is too early. He crosses to the stove, pours himself a cu of coffee, and sits down to drink it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey has decided on a change of costume from his last g and this time he goes for the old-fashioned velvet smokin jacket and silk foulard. Over this he puts on a light  overcoat. Then he assembles medicines, toilet articles an money, putting them all into a small satchel. Finally, he puts on his hat and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Lancey's progress as far as the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melba and Shooter have finished dressing, and he waits by the door while she does the inevitable last-minute things her makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made up my mind to this. I ain't  going to give him any help till he  needs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're taking a stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what if he starts off lucky and  stays ahead of the game the whole  way. It could happen, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll make it happen, Baby. I've  got faith in you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hands are at 7:25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid is looking at the clock tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more around the square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi drives away from CAMERA following The Kid's  instruction. CAMERA PANS to the front of the Dorset Hotel which they have just passed. It is fifty years old or mor no longer elegant but still respectable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is standing at ease among old friends, sipping a creme menthe frappe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a friendly town, St. Louis.  I've always said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES to take in the people around him, one after  another. The Shooter is there, and Pig and Sokal and Hoba and Melba and Hoban's woman and a couple of other women w main attributes are physical, and Bill Schlaegel. Out of  town representatives include LADY FINGERS, who is about f down on her luck but still cheerful and remarkably energe and YELLER, a light-skinned Negro who has achieved statur in what is mainly a white man's world, through diplomacy a quick wit. The room is the large living-room of a once  splendid suite; there are enough chairs and couches aroun the walls to accommodate a good many spectators, while th middle of the room has been cleared for a round table wit seven chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't seen much of you though,  last seven, eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climate, Shooter. In my declining  years, I spend more and more time in  Florida and the Gulf Coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of folks been figuring another  reason you was keeping clear of the  three rivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What reason is that, Lady Fingers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cincinnati Kid. (laughs) That the way it is, Lancey? You been  scared of The Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I be scared of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right you should! I'm telling  you, that boy going to make your  stomach ulcer bleed before the night  is out. He's close to murder. I seen  him give a fella the shakes so bad  on a fourth card, it took a pint of  corn liquor to settle him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey notices that most of the people around him have tu to look at the doorway. He glances in the same direction a casual sort of way.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING THE KID
dialogues.text: He saunters toward Lancey. Almost everyone greets him, an he responds to as many as he can. Melba intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mow the man down, sugar pie, make it  quick and bloody. Been too many lean  years for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to take Shooter right along  with Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about the old Shooter.  He's been factory rebuilt. A new  spirit dwelleth in him, and his gaze  is on distant hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid would like these cryptic words explained, but Lad Fingers descends on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you showed up after all. You're a  braver boy than I thought, so much  the worse for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'll be sorry I come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bound to. That Lancey ain't human,  he's one of them barracuda fish.  He's liable to bleed to death, right  on a flush hand before he give up to  you. I seen him gut a fella so bad,  the fella quit and got up and spit  red in the john and went square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid sees Lancey approaching, and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Kid. Pleasure to know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey. I been looking forward a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. You seem to know about  everybody. Yeller from New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Yeller? Still feeling  salty with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgiven long since. (to Lancey) We had a little jurisdictional  dispute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hustled a couple of boys, right in  his territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I tried to tell him our rules  down there. Colored marks are for  colored hustlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I tried to tell him how I got no  prejudice. When I'm on the edge of  my stake, I hustle anybody at all,  regardless of race, creed or color.  Anybody at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I figured I was doin' you a  favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they both laugh over a private memory and shake  hands, obviously old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lancey) Did you know Old Cottonhead died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I hadn't heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heart give out in a high-low game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to The Kid) How you feel, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best. You think maybe we ought  to see if we can stir up some action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Lancey. You're the -- (correcting himself) You're our guest in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm kind of in the mood to  play a little cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we ought to be able to get a  game together in this crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But first you take a look at things --  make sure everything's the way you  want it. I already been around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns toward the center of the room. The Shooter follo him.

dialogues.speaker: AT POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The old, solidly built wooden table has been covered with white linen cloth on top of a blanket. The cloth is tied  down under the rim so that the surface of the table is fl tight and cushioned by the blanket. The Kid presses his  fingers into it to test these factors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an old table. Everything's pretty  old in this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's solid, that's what counts. And  you got the top fixed perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey comes into the SHOT behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light all right for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred watt bulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, excellent. Okay with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Shooter's set us up just  great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, gents. Tried to do the  best I could. (looks from one to  the other) Cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good a time as any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Hoban! Okay! (to Kid and Lancey) You both know Joe Hoban. He's a draw  poker man, but clean and straight as  they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoban comes into the SHOT with a dispatch case, which he  sets on the table. He unlocks it with a key and turns it  upside down. Thirty sealed decks of cards spill on the ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come from the St. Louis Bridge  Club, but they're poker size cards.  They been bonded by the club steward  and I seen him take them out of the  safe. Shooter, Lady Fingers and me  pick them up and come straight here  with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoban's selling them to us at five  dollars a pack, with the usual  guarantee. If it's proved any deck  is spooked, he pays off the losers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Louis Bridge Club, eh? Steward  still that old yard bird Okra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed) That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not noticing; to Kid) Old stud man, Okra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a character. Quite a character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously) Nobody heard from me what the cards  were for, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a quick exchange of glances all around as the ot three realize what the imaginary suspicion is behind Hoba defensive reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kid) Been ten years since I seen or spoke  to Old Okra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay, fine. Don't worry about it,  Lancey. Who's sitting down with us,  Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four of us. Me, Pig, Yeller and Doc  Sokal. If that's all right with you  both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. (to Kid) Shall we have a look at the decks?

dialogues.speaker: KID AND LANCEY
dialogues.text: with the pile of decks and the empty dispatch case on the table in front of them. They start checking the decks one one, each putting the ones he has covered in a pile for t other's consideration. They examine the seals and the  cellophane visually, and they also sniff both ends for th odor of a hot iron. By the time they are through with thi process; The Kid has found three decks he isn't satisfied with, and Lancy two. The Kid passes his three rejects to  Lancey, who tosses them back into the dispatch case witho looking at them. Then Lancey tries to submit his two to T Kid, but The Kid waves them away, and Lancey throws them, too, into the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Kid, what's your game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the other four players, who  have come up to the table, still not taking chairs until  Lancey and The Kid have chosen theirs. Though Lancey's  question is purely ritualistic, they look to The Kid for reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind stud poker if that's  okay with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no objections to stud. (to the others) Gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consulting the others is a formality, but all four of the Yeller, Shooter, Pig and Sokal -- nod or grunt or otherwi indicate assent.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING BILL
dialogues.text: across the room, he is indicating to The Shooter that he' like a word with him before play begins.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING SHOOTER
dialogues.text: He detaches himself from the group and sidles inconspicuo over to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell The Kid I have a suite on the  fifth floor. He can drop up during  the breaks. Bedroom all for him any  time he wants a nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's thoughtful of you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a thoughtful man. I hope you  are.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The Kid gestures to Lancey to choose his seat. Lancey  acknowledges the courtesy, glances at the window and pick himself a chair facing away from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Privilege of age. Can't take the  glare of the morning sun in my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid, following protocol, moves to a seat directly acr from Lancey's. The Shooter takes his place at the table  halfway between The Kid and Lancey, and pulls the twenty- five eligible packs of cards to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to have the usual brandy  and coffee on hand, Kid? Anything  special for you, Lancey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes, Shooter. Creme de menthe  frappe. Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances around) You got that, Hoban? (to the table) Gentlemen, if there are no objections,  I'm the dealer. These rooms have  been contracted for, and there will  be an ante of ten dollars per chair,  per day. During the breaks for me,  Old Lady Fingers has agreed to deal,  but she don't care to be a player --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do too care!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to reveal Lady Fingers as she steps from amon the spectators to a place behind Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't afford to play, that's the  real truth. Had a bad year and I'm  way over my edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers will get three dollars  an hour from the ante, plus her room  and food, and a five-minute break  every hour. Gents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Shooter man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't see me when you need  me, call room three-oh-eight. (taps Lancey's shoulder) You know who else ain't with us no  more? Miriam, widow used to run the  kitchen game to South Chi. Lost two  month's Relief at blackjack, coal  dealer cut her credit, and she froze  in her bed.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLAYERS
dialogues.text: The Kid has taken his roll from his pocket and is countin it out rapidly. The other players watch, interested to se how much he is putting out. After counting out one stack thirty hundreds, he distributes the rest in stacks of  twenties, tens and fives, folding each bill over once as  protection against picking up more than one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is a game of five- card stud poker. There is no limit.  A dead man has one half hour to raise  his roll outside and get back in the  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid has completed his count.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING LANCEY
dialogues.text: He takes the money from his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five grand? Nice, tidy sum. I'll put  out the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to Yeller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I don't know what I'm doing  sitting down with you titans, but  maybe it's worth putting up five  thousand for the educational value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to Pig as he brings out a roll and drops it  casually in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll play with what I have in my  pocket till I have to send out for  more. Twenty-seven, twenty-eight  hundred, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS past The Kid to Sokal, who is counting out bi from an impressive roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five G's, I'm with it. Don't mean  I'm goin' blow it all, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to The Shooter, who is counting out a smaller stake than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last and certainly least --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his money out without counting it, takes a deck o cards, rips the cellophane off it, takes the jokers and t them offhandedly to one side, not seeming to take aim.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING THE JOKERS
dialogues.text: Heads turn as the cards sail through the air in unison,  landing inside The Shooter's familiar hat, which is resti crown down on the mantelpiece. The spectators gape at the display of dexterity.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING THE SHOOTER
dialogues.text: He begins to shuffle and all eyes are upon him, not from  suspicion but from pure admiration. He is in peak form,  shuffling six times, once for each player and then slappi the cards down before Lancey, who is to the right of him, with an empty chair in between.

dialogues.speaker: LANCEY
dialogues.text: He waives his privilege of cutting with a barely percepti nod.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The Shooter acknowledges the compliment with the same sor of gesture. Then he begins to deal in his magnificently  precise way, pitching each card so that it comes to a sto six inches in front of the player's money and in clear vi of everyone at the table.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTER'S HANDS
dialogues.text: With Sokal in b.g. It is notable that as The Shooter comp dealing hole cards and switches to the first up card, the is no visible difference in the motion of his hands. He c the cards as he deals them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven, nine, trey, nine, ace, and  The Shooter guns up a ten. Ace bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dealer folds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the sawbuck.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BEHIND KID
dialogues.text: He looks at his hole card: an ace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The Shooter deals again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King to the seven, pair of nines,  deuce to the trey, queen-nine, ace- eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nines bet twenty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each other player folds in turn. The Shooter pulls in the cards, and The Kid pulls in the seventy dollars. The Shoo shuffles and deals again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen, ten, king, four, ace again,  and a king for The Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace bets ten dollars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King over.

dialogues.speaker: HOBAN AND BILL
dialogues.text: They are perched on the back of a love seat at the far en of the room, with their feet on the arms. This gives them view of the table through a pair of opera glasses they sh but they are far enough from it to be able to discuss the hands freely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooter won't stay on a king or an  ace if there's another one showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he have to have in the hole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten or better. With no other ten  showing.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The second round has been dealt. Sokal has a queen-eight, The Kid a pair of tens, Pig a king- seven, Lancey an ace- five. Yeller, like The Shooter, has folded on the first c The Kid makes the same bet of twenty dollars, and the oth three remaining players drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhesitatingly, The Shooter pulls in the cards, separates them into four or five piles, and tears each pile in two. glances around, and Hoban comes up behind him. The Shoote hands him the torn-up cards and unseals another pack, goi through the same routine of throwing the jokers into his  hat. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is around midnight, and there is a more settled look t the game; some of the players have removed their coats, a there is a good deal of smoke in the air. The Kid has a c of coffee by him, presumably with brandy in it; Lancey ha his frappe; Pig is drinking whiskey; the Shooter and Yell have bottles of bear. It is the end of a hand. With about six hundred dollars in the pot, Pig, who has been called, turns over his hole card triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aces over eights. (waits for a challenge,  but the others turn  their cards) Thank you, gents. (as he pulls in money,  to Yeller) Be a laugh if the two champs ended  up cleaned.

dialogues.speaker: LANCEY
dialogues.text: He barely notices Pig's remark.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: He barely notices Lancey's reaction to Pig's remark. CAMERA MOVES among the spectators, who also have a more  settled look about them. There is a bar, attended by a  uniformed HOTEL BELLMAN, and most of the people are drink We see in passing a couple go through the door to the bed and close it behind them. CAMERA HOLDS on the love seat a Bill rejoin Hoban on their perch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) What do you expect first five or six  hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still feeling each other out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pig's ahead about a grand, Shooter  maybe three hundred. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: CARDS BEING DEALT
dialogues.text: Sokal gets a nine of clubs, The Kid a six, Pig a queen, Y a king, Lancey a jack, and The Shooter a four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the players. There is less oral accompaniment to the betting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King says twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey calls, Shooter drops, Sokal calls, The Kid drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In for twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dealing) To the nine a ten, to the queen a  seven, to the king a jack, and to  the jack a jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pair of jacks will venture a hundred  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has the nine and  ten of clubs showing) I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after studying the  board) Up two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding) Leave it to the rich folk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey could be laying for him with  three jacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pig don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: Lancey puts in his money and so does Sokal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sticking.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: Shooter deals another round: an eight of clubs to Sokal, second seven to Pig, a ten to Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible straight flush, pair of  sevens. Pair of jacks are still high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check to the sevens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual) Bet the size of the pot. Nine hundred  and eighty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In for nine eighty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with Lancey? I thought he'd  raise with three jacks or drop with  two pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably thinks Pig's faking the  queens. Anyhow, Doc's liable take  them both with a straight or a flush.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: There is a good deal of suspense hanging on each card as Shooter deals. Sokal gets a five of diamonds, and his  disappointment is too great to conceal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busted, no flush, no straight. Pair  of sevens with a queen gets a nine.  To the pair of jacks, a trey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting his money,  trying to be calm) Pair of sevens will bet whatever I  got here. Twenty-four hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call your twenty-four hundred --

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He watches Lancey, puzzled; this isn't what he had expect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and raise you whatever I have  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid relaxes; this is more the way he figured it.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: Lancey is completely calm. Pig is shattered, his whole wo suddenly blown apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes to fourteen hundred fifty  dollars, Pig. Don't imagine you'll  have any problem promoting that much  in half an hour -- plus whatever you  care to raise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Pig, which doesn't make it any easier for him. He just sits there, his hands shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen fifty to the queens. You  want to take your half hour, Pig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another long moment before Pig flips over his up cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm out. Out of the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Lancey with malevolence. Lancey turns over hi up cards and tosses them in front of The Shooter. Pig sud lunges toward the cards, wanting a look at Lancey's hole  card, but Lancey is too quick for him and pushes the card into the pack The Shooter is assembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pig) You Tap City?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pig is suffering, weighing the advantages and disadvantag of making the dread admission. Finally he nods. The Shoot takes a ten dollar bill from his own stake, and the other four remaining players each add a ten. The Shooter pushes the money toward Pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you and Hilda were quits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other players look at The Shooter to see if he is goi to accept this statement at face value. He nods, that he  does, and each man contributes another ten. The Shooter p the second fifty to Pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you around, Pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) So long, Pig -- See you -- 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS him to the door. The spectators make room him, no one saying anything. At the door, Pig turns back his valedictory gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck -- Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: LANCEY
dialogues.text: He has been rearranging his money, but Pig's words make h head jerk up and toward the door. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal the other players, who react dismay to the breach of form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shouldn't have said that. Not  after taking Tap City from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His woman's been giving him a rough  time. Wants him to quit and go square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his age? Crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to wish anybody luck, doesn't  bother me. Personally, I don't figure  The Kid needs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, the tension is gone. But just to make sure, Th Shooter pushes his chair back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's early, men, but what  about taking a little break? (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melba fills a beer glass from a bottle and serves it to T Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melba) It always distresses me, a man  reaching his middle years and still  having no assurance of next week's  income.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. I like a man  to have plenty of assurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter's gaze wanders o.s. CAMERA MOVES to FEATURE t objects of his attention, who are Lady Fingers, Lancey an The Kid. The two men would like to talk to each other, bu Lady Finger's is monopolizing Lancey, and he doesn't want offend her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spider Man died kind of slow. First  he give them a kidney, then his gall  bladder, and then they taking his  whole damn stomach. You remember  Spider Man, run the dice table down  at Turk's Club to Memphis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Oh, Spider Man, sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died kind of slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter comes to Lancey's rescue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need your help, Lady Fingers... to  make arrangements for food and  shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whisks her away. Lancey and The Kid, finally facing ea other alone, don't quite know how to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Nice-looking broads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a pretty thing to watch  what you done to Pig with those jacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Kid. From you, that's nice  to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he bet out first, he was ready  to think you had them back to back.  Even when he bet the size of the  pot, he figured there was still a  chance you were laying for him. But  when you called him, I could see it  in his eyes he thought you had jacks  and tens, and I knew you had him  hooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew, did you? Before I raised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, I seen what you were pulling  all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey is a bit taken aback by The Kid's confident assert but he manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been to Miami, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful town, lot of loose money  around. You ought to come down some  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Lot of room down there.  Another spot you ought to work someday  is Reno, Nevada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to have nerves though. So  much going on. Action everywhere you  turn. You lose the feel of the cards  when you're in so much action day  in, day out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to make it out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's different levels of action  there -- you'd find yours, any kind  you could ask for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I generally stick to stud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, for eating money. But  you know how it is, I like to lay  off once in a while and try craps.  Nothing serious -- I don't even think  of it as work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do that. I'll take a night off  and shoot a little casino. Or even  blackjack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your age, you don't need a regular  vacation every year. But me, I have  to forget the grind for a couple of  weeks. I go to this place near Delray  Beach, and the whole time I don't  play anything but bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's interesting. I could go for  bridge if there was a way to do it  without partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not keeping you from your woman,  am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a slight  hesitation) No. We're -- she's gone away for a  while. We're not sure we're looking  for the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping Christian would run  with me and wouldn't try to make a  big deal out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she tried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and now I don't know. I don't  figure a man can change his way  because the way I see it a man's  lucky he's got something going for  him that he can hold on to. A man  can't change his way for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo, a man can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been wondering if it isn't maybe a  better idea not to look for a fixed  thing. Just tie in to something nice  when you're away from the action,  and enjoy it, and let it wear itself  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) That's very interesting you should  say that. You're pretty young to  have figured things out already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well she didn't understand how it  was with me and ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warmly) Between us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't but a few people, I guess  who would understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as The Kid doesn't  finish) Kid, you're the best stud man I've  seen in 35 years of action. You know  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when it comes to broads, which  is getting to be an academic problem --  I can look back now to the two or  three I ever considered I might want  to spend the rest of my life with,  and you know what? I like it...  looking back on them, that is -- (then) I always got a lot of companionship  out of a good book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very educational, hearing what  it's like for a man your age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to be of help. And it's good we  had this little talk so I know we  can be friends regardless what  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds good to me. I didn't  think you was coming in at me like a  grudge match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No room for any kind of emotion in a  fair game of stud. I learned that a  long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for some action, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other and then exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers is sitting in Shooter's place, rippling and  shuffling the cards. Yeller, Sokal, and The Shooter are a either sitting at the table or standing near it. Lancey,  followed by The Kid, returns to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a whole New Deal. Good hands  all around. Prosperity for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still good, Fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting crippled up, Lancey. Not  many of the old gang left. You heard  Whistling Sam was gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the one got called to the morgue  to identify him. I don't suppose you  seen anybody been run over by a twelve- ton bulldozer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, can't say that I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go out of your way. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning sunlight is streaming in.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The Kid, facing the sun, wears his eyeshade. The Shooter resumed the deal and now hands out last cards to Sokal, T Kid and himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet the pot. Four hundred and twenty  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, gents. Makes me exactly even.  This kind of a game, that's a smart  place to quit. (takes his money off  the table) Just do the dealing, if that's all  right with everybody. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: It is later in the morning. Three players are left in the hand on the last card: Yeller with nothing higher than a  jack, Lancey with a king-queen showing and Sokal with an king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace-king is the high man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot the works. (counts it out) Nine hundred and thirty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting out the money) What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unhappily) Doesn't matter. If you can call me,  you beat me. Ace-king high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning an ace) Ace-king-queen high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to The Kid) I had them both with a pair of fives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winds it up for me, men. And I can't  say it's been a pleasure. (despairingly) That one I was sure I could steal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey has a built-in burglar alarm.  I'm also withdrawing from the field  of battle, gentlemen. Settle for the  seventeen hundred I've already  dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeller pulls in the money in front of him. There is now a $19,500 left on the table, $11,500 in front of Lancey, $8 in front of The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to The Kid) Well, just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just the two of us. Deal them,  Shooter Man. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: There is around $1,500 in the pot. Shooter deals an unhel card to Lancey's pair of aces, and a nine to The Kid's ki queen-ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost you a grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compulsory call, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid turns up a jack and pulls in the money. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The last bet has been made and there is about $3000 in th pot. Lancey exposes his hole card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pair, jacks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kings up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes in the money. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: There is $2500 in the pot. Lancey shows a pair of kings, Kid an ace and three odd cards. The Shooter deals a nine Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He is watching The Shooter intently. FEATURING THE SHOOTER'S HANDS - KID'S P.O.V. The dealing motion looks perfectly legitimate as The Shoo gives The Kid an ace. Lancey's hand reaches into the SHOT turn over his up cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studded again.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He takes the money in slowly, his eyes on The Shooter. No the distribution of money has been reversed. The Kid has  something under $12,000, Lancey something under $8,000.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOOTER
dialogues.text: He avoids meeting The Kid's gaze. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: On the fourth card Lancey shows a pair of sevens, The Kid pair of eights and a ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid lifts his hole card and we see it is a ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to watch The Shooter. FEATURING THE SHOOTER'S HANDS - KID'S P.O.V. Again there is no indication of improper dealing as The  Shooter gives Lancey an odd card and The Kid a ten, compl his full house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. I can't beat three sevens. (then as The Shooter's  eyes flicker with  surprise) I'd like a break to get some food  and sleep -- I'm winners so it isn't  up to me to say it but I'm saying it  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. After a moment The Shooter follows. Lancey watc them go then rises, apparently still fresh and strong. La Fingers joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) My dear, that young man is a stud  poker-playing son-of-a-bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' to you, Lancey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lancey looks at her a moment, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Not yet he isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves through the crowd, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM - BILL'S SUITE - THE KID & SHOOTER They are alone in the room. Shooter is uncomfortable and  would like to be elsewhere but The Kid is standing in fro of the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, just what the hell are you trying  to pull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to bluff it) Nothing -- what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid grabs him and slams him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Shooter Man -- you been feeding  me cards for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry and ashamed) The hell I was. (he waits a brief  moment then eases  away from The Kid) Christ, Kid, even if I was you  couldn't spot it -- I'm too good a  mechanic for anybody to spot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him and  slamming him against  the wall again) But I was looking for it, Shooter --  four times you give me the cards I  need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little shrill) You seen it before often enough. One  player draws four good ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never in a game when I been told  ahead the dealer has a stake in my  coming out on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slumping) My woman told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me enough to make me start  thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost pleading) Why should you bitch if I give you a  little help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you dumb bastard? -- You have  to ask me why. (ready to hit him) I could break you apart for what  you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing off) Kid, you got to understand. It wasn't  my idea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well who the hell's was it then --  Schlaegel? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the squeeze on me Kid and  he's meaner than hell. He'll cut me  up if I don't come through. (then) You think I wanted to deal a phony  game? You think it don't mean  something to me? I never done a  crooked thing before in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ass bleeds for you -- Now you get  straight on this. No fix. You come  along straight or I blow it wide  open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's liable to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't goin' to do nothin' to you  except pay off because I'm goin' to  win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a hell of a chance to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't goin' to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost yelling at  him) He ain't goin' to know. (then quietly) Shooter, I'm goin' to win this one --  win it my way -- and you ride with  me or you're out, finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ride with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not forget it -- now beat  it. I need some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooter looks at him, then moves towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mr. Schlaegel I accept his offer  to use the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shooter goes out. The Kid crosses to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I want to be called at 4 p.m. on the  nose. For sure -- Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the privacy of his room he shows how close he is to  exhaustion. Wearily, he sits on the bed and begins to rem his shoes. Then, catching his reflection in the mirror,  straightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet he isn't. But he damn well  might.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: She is in the final stages of undressing. CAMERA MOVES wi her as she steps to The Kid's bedside and gets into bed w him. Having accomplished this without waking him, she spe into his ear in imitation of a hotel phone operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, sir. It's exactly  four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He awakens in considerable confusion. Melba is amused by difficulty in adjusting to his circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really only about twenty-five  to four. You can stay right where  you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to think I'm getting  too personal, but you mind telling  me how the hell you come to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't remember last  night? We drank all that champagne  and you said "Let's get married right  away," and we chartered a plane to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it -- (then) Where's Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I locked the door. It's incredible  the way you invariably worry about  The Shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's incredible the way you invariably  don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worrying takes time and we don't  have a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to sit down again at  half past four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it really matter so much to you  now, that sense of obligation to The  Shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking about Shooter) I got no obligations to The Shooter. (then to Melba) Or to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obligations are not what I have in  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is shaving. Apparently much stronger but his hand is  shaking. He looks at it. It steadies. After a moment he s a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on the shower door as the SOUND of running wate ceases. The Kid can be seen indistinctly through the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reach me a towel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melba, who is dressed again and applying her lipstick, co into the SHOT, takes a towel from a rack and hands it to after he opens the shower door. He gives himself a quick  once-over with it, the secures it around his waist, steps out of the shower stall, and begins the process of shavin Melba meanwhile finishes restoring her makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You any idea how much The Shooter  has involved in this game of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Schlaegel bet as much on me as I  heard, I guess he'd pay a nice piece  of change to be sure I won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worse than that. Schlaegel staked  him for three years. He has his hooks  so deep in Shooter Man, he'll take  out his liver when he pulls them  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid stops shaving and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asking me to go along with the  fix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you to consider whether  your ego is worth destroying another  man's whole life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still working for him. On my  time you're still working for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of switch is this? You  criticize me for trying to chippie  on him, then I get a little loyal  and you're at me for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I don't hold it against you.  You wanting to make things right for  him -- but this game I handle my way --  win, lose, or draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolls and coffee for the hard-headed  hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to take in the view of the bedroom as she cro it to the door, talking as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me Kid there is too much at  stake for us to rely on your doing  it on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has paused at the door to finish her sentence. Now sh unlocks and opens it -- to Christian. Melba is so taken a she can't do anything but stand there holding the door op The Kid, in the bathroom in f.g., is similarly frozen in tracks. After a moment Christian advances into the room. REVERSE ANGLE - CHRISTIAN IN F.G. The scene as it looks to Christian is circumstantially  incriminating. CAMERA MOVES with her gaze from The Kid to the one mussed bed, to Melba. The faces and the silence o the two people are even more incriminating than the  circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Kid. Hello, Melba. (a pause) You said wait home 'til you let me  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I said. We took a  break in the game to catch some sleep.  Shooter sent his woman up here to  wake me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I woke him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't take much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't find it any trouble. (awkwardly) Well, you children don't need me,  that's for sure. See you downstairs. (to Christian) You, too, honey, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be around if The Kid wants me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you, Melba. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Por nada, as they say. It was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks past CAMERA and a moment later comes the SOUND the door closing behind her. The Kid, who has moved into bedroom, crosses to his clothes on a chair, and picks up undershorts and trousers. He returns to the bathroom, usi the door for partial concealment as he removes his towel puts on his shorts and trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been to the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've got my bag downstairs. Maybe  I'll take it over later on tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your Mama and Papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. How's the game going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid fastens his trousers and returns to the basin to  give his face a last few strokes with the razor and wash the soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's come to be just me and Lancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes back into the bedroom to finish dressing. As his movement brings him fairly close to Christian, he realize he hasn't kissed her, and repairs the omission before put his shirt on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after the kiss) I was wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my mind on the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. And I don't want to rattle  you. We got plenty to talk about,  but it can all wait. Except I want  to say this. I came back because I  figured if it was going to work with  us, it's silly me sitting home with  Mama while you're playing your big  game. I mean if I'm any use to you  at all, this is when it's most  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To The Kid preoccupied by the game and the fix, feeling b affection and guilt. The idea that she can be any use to against Lancey is one he can't grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came, Christian. You  got as much right here as anybody. (then) More right, I should have said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yes. The change I come out  with when I win this one, you're  going to be the one to spend it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back) Look, I said I'm glad you came --  and that's all until I wrap this up --  I'm a poker player, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. After a moment he exits. She follows.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: It is evening. Lady Fingers deals a first up card to the players. The Kid gets an eight, Lancey a jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eight'll try two bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning his card) No stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers scoops up the cards, shuffles them into the  rest of the deck, submits it to Lancey for his cut, and d them another two cards apiece -- all in the space of seco The Kid gets a queen, Lancey a nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning his card) No stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA starts on Yeller, who is stretched out on the love with his eyes closed and PANS UP to INCLUDE Hoban, who si at the observation post with the binoculars. Yeller speak without opening his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naaa, Kid paired kings. He wins a  hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES on PAST a window, showing it is night outsid past a group of other spectators; past Bill, Shooter and  Melba who watch the game grimly; and finally to the table where The Shooter is dealing again. The Kid is down to hi undershirt, and even Lancey has made a few concessions to comfort. The players have just been dealt their third car Christian moves up to stand behind The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen bets another C-note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding) Take it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go read a magazine, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates. Then moves away. Lancey watches this. (TIME LAPSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later at night. The magazine lies open on Christian lap; she is staring absently into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, gents. I'm declaring a  break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The announcement rouses Christian from her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers is in the dealer's chair. The two players lo pretty weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers puts down the deck. Picks up a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) Same deck is good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a new deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright -- A new deck then,  Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Fingers looks at the two men for a long moment. Puts the cards down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to deal? Then deal them  yourselves. I'm going to the john.  I'm going to get something to eat,  and I'm going to take a nap. You  barracudas can snap all you want but  at each other -- I'm taking a break  and if you don't like it you can  both go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and stalks off. Lancey and The Kid look at each other for a moment, then both grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we been told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) See you in about 3/4 of an hour,  Lancey, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it an hour. Old bones need a  little more time to loosen up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning it) Listen, I think it is amazing you've  been able to keep going this long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he heads for the door, Lancey reacts to this. Then sta and looks around the room. Groups of people stand in the  shadows watching silently, not hostile but certainly not  friendly. He is The Man but he is getting beat and nobody sorry. After a moment he turns and leaves from a side doo CAMERA PANS to HOLD on Christian as she stops The Kid by door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) Eric --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously) Your fan on the fifth floor wants  you to have a bite with him. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better, Kid. You don't, you're  only making worse trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian scans both their faces as they talk... concerne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think so. (to Christian) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Nothing you have to worry  about. I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the door. Christian looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and The Kid are sitting at a room-service table. Bil nibbles at some cheese and crackers while The Kid tackles large steak. Felix, the chauffeur, stands in attendance o them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would be better if you  and I sat down together to see if we  couldn't work out our differences.  Felix!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions to Felix, indicating a wine bottle on the tabl Felix steps over and refills The Kid's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I told The Shooter goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying no before we've even  discussed it? Am I to feel all my  arguments will be wasted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
